content.description: Three distinct rock/climbing styles as you move up. starts on blocky choss with lots of jugs up to a large ledge. Get a solid rest for the slightly overhanging crux up a curving crack and a big reach over the bulge. A much smaller ledge gives a decent rest before the slabby finish with one more crux midway. end at the ledge directly under the lookout bolder. could top out if you're comfortable climbing above the TR anchor/if you set the anchor higher up. would be a great route to bolt, I think it would be too run out to safely trad.
content.protection: Tree anchor (three good ones within 20ft of edge), I'd avoid using the large mostly hollow tree near the edge
content.location: just past the hillside area along the path, turn left toward the river at the natural lookout. the top of the cliff has the name phoenix painted in pink. Set TR anchor well over the edge, there are a few small features that may tear up your rope if you don't. Rap down or walk down the trail another 50ft to an easy path down.

content.description: Almost a sit start. pockets under small overhang and feet under the low roof, move left over the bulge then right onto the arete. finish at the heart-shaped crimp left of the arete.
content.location: looking toward the river it's on the left side of the bowl, underneath the rocks that everyone takes selfies on.

content.description: Start in the back of the small cave, work through jugs, pockets and crimps and finish with a big move to the final jug.  Top out.  Would be pretty cool route if it wasn't a bit of a butt dragger and the graffiti on it
content.location: 10 feet uphill from the Hillside Boulder.

content.description: Start slightly right of Backstabber and move up on some crimps and traverse left. Same finish as Backstabber
Start matched on chalked holds bellow graffiti then traverse left through the mono crux too some sharp jugs.
Hosts a few decent moderates. And maybe couple sport routes if ever developed.
